comments:
Further strangeness to bug 64951

* condition is i == 57
* change to Java perspective
* shutdown workspace
* restart workspace
* re-launch last (debug mode)
* Error dialog appears claiming a runtime exception occurred in the condition. 
The error dialog appears 4 to 6 times (stacked) and this is in the log:

com.sun.jdi.IncompatibleThreadStateException: Thread was not suspended
at java.lang.Throwable.<init>(Throwable.java)

ionalBreakpointEvent(JavaLineBreakpoint.java:441)

ointEvent(JavaLineBreakpoint.java:367)

(EventDispatcher.java:221)

Terminating and restarting the target works OK. Seems to be a problem with 
evaluating the condition on startup.

Using the TCP Spy I found that on the case of plug-in startup, we craete two 
breakpoint requests in the same location. This might meen we are trying to 
evaluate twice on each suspend. On the normal case (non plug-in startup), we 
only create one breakpoint request. Issues:

* Fix array index problems for Drop-to-frame when no frames
* If there is more than one breakpoint event at the same location with a 
condition - only evaluate one 
* Only create one breakpoint request on startup

The evalations are done in sequence. The problem is that the first evaluation 
completes and decides to resume the thread since the condition is "false", and 
then the second evaluation runs into trouble (thread not suspended).

The breakpoints are added twice since the target inits itself by getting all 
registered breakpoints and adding them on startup. However, the first time the 
breakpoint manager inits its breakpoints, it sends add notifications. Thus, 
the target gets them twice. Issues:

* Should the BP manager fire add notification on startup?
* A target should not add the same breakpoint more than once

Fixed. Changes in

* JavaLineBreakpoint - index out of bounds check (i.e. if thread has no frames)
* JDIStackFrame - index of out of bounds check
* JDIDebugTarget - only add breakpoints that have not already been added. When 
re-installing breakpoints, remove breakpoints first (so they get re-added).

This will still leave two issues, which I will file as new bugs reports but do 
not plan to address for 3.0:

* BreakpointManager fires add notification on initialization
* Two conditional breakpoints at the same location will cause trouble (but the 
user can't do this, so do not plan to address in 3.0)
(Note: fix was pre-verified by Kevin Barnes).
